definition:
Let $\mathcal{C}$ be a category. The *identity functor* of $\mathcal{C}$
is the unique functor, written $I_{\mathcal{C}}$, such that for every
object $A$ and every morphism $\alpha$ in $\mathcal{C}$, we have
$$I_{\mathcal{C}}(A)=A\quad\mbox{ and }\quad I_{\mathcal{C}}(\alpha)=\alpha.$$
To verify that $I_{\mathcal{C}}$ is indeed a functor, we note that
$I_{\mathcal{C}}(1_A)=1_A=1_{I_{\mathcal{C}}(A)}$, where $1_A$ is the
identity morphism of $A$, and
$I_{\mathcal{C}}(\alpha\circ\beta)=\alpha\circ \beta=I_{\mathcal{C}}(\alpha)\circ I_{\mathcal{C}}(\beta)$.

For any functor $F:\mathcal{C}\to \mathcal{D}$, we have
$F\circ I_{\mathcal{C}}= I_{\mathcal{D}}\circ F=F$.

Since every category gives rise to its unique identity functor, we can
think of *the identity functor* $I$ as a (covariant) functor on **Cat**,
the category of (small) categories. It is given by taking any category
$\mathcal{C}$ to itself and any functor $F:\mathcal{C}\to \mathcal{D}$
to itself.
